articles.title: Evanston celebrates World Migratory Bird Day on May 10
articles.author: Jim Brown
articles.summary: World Migratory Bird Day is celebrated on the second Saturday in May in the U.S. and Canada. More than 50 million birds will migrate through Cook County this spring. Evanston's lakefront, the North Shore Channel and the Chicago River are important parts of the Mississippi Flyway. The City of Evanston works with volunteers to create natural areas attractive and safe for migrating birds. Mayor Daniel Biss read a proclamation at the April 28 City Council Meeting.

articles.title: Linking climate change adaptation with means of implementation
articles.summary: Climate change adaptation is a key part of climate action and one of the pillars of the Paris Agreement. Most adaptation measures take place at the local level and are specific to their geographic, environmental, and socioeconomic context. The process of developing National Adaptation Plans is led by national governments. Multilateral decisions on climate finance and adaptation estimate adaptation finance needs 'at USD 215-387 billion annually for up until 2030'. Sri Lanka's first Biennial Transparency Report highlights several barriers that hinder the implementation of adaptation measures.

articles.title: Pre-monsoon showers push heatwave away in Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: Nalla Babu
articles.summary: Andhra Pradesh has experienced an unusually pleasant summer so far thanks to regular pre-monsoon showers and heavy rainfall. The IMD has forecast above-normal maximum and minimum temperatures and normal to above-average rainfall for Andhra Pradesh in May. The probability of the state registering above normal maximum temperatures is between 33.5% and 55%. The number of heatwave days in the state is likely to be fewer in May except in north coastal areas.

articles.title: World-first genetic index helps Aussie farmers breed heat tolerant cows
articles.summary: Trevor Parrish is a fourth-generation dairy farmer in Kangaroo Valley, south-west of Sydney. He is one of the first farmers in NSW to use the Heat Tolerance Australian Breeding Value (ABV) to breed for heat tolerance in his herd of Holstein heifers.

articles.title: Nature in the Neighborhood: Welcoming the migrants back
articles.author: Guest Commentary
articles.summary: This March I went to Nebraska to witness the sandhill crane migration. It is the largest migration of cranes in North America and the world. Dr. Jane Goodall calls it one of the most spectacular events in the natural world. According to Audubon, at least 4,000 species of birds are regular migrants. They migrate to find better food sources, breed, raise their young and escape the harsh winter weather.

articles.title: Accelerate transition
articles.author: Khan Faraz
articles.summary: The past decade has been the warmest on record. The World Economic Forum's Global Risks Report 2025 identifies environmental risks as half of the top 10 global concerns. The emission of greenhouse gases and global warming are the main drivers of these risks. The transition towards green energy is a welcome development but more needs to be done to phase out fossil fuels.

articles.title: Behind smoke and ashes: How Israeli forest fires mask ugly truth of settler-colonialism
articles.author: Ivan Kesic The
articles.summary: The latest wave of wildfires sweeping through the occupied Palestinian territories has once again drawn attention to Israel's pillaging of the Palestinian land. Israel's practice of using afforestation as a new year's resolution has been condemned by Ivan Kesic and other activists.

articles.title: Book review: Birdland by Jon Gower
articles.author: 6 minute read
articles.summary: Birdland by Jon Gower is about birds and the bird-people and places of Britain. It's part memoir, part nonfiction, part plea and enthralling. The avian information is interwoven with music, art and literary references, encounters with other bird-folk and Gower's own birding exploits.

articles.title: Report exposes $28 trillion in damage tied to five powerful companies: 'The veil of plausible deniability doesn't exist anymore'
articles.author: Christine Dulion
articles.summary: Saudi Aramco, Gazprom, Chevron, ExxonMobil, BP and others caused $28 trillion in global economic damages from extreme heat between 1991 and 2020. A third of the damages could be traced to just five companies: Saudi Aramco ($2.05 trillion), Gazprom ($2 trillion), Chevron ($1.98 trillion), ExxonMobil ($ 1.91 trillion) and BP ($1,45 trillion).

articles.title: Accelerating our efforts to protect Earth's oceans
articles.author: Rita Maria
articles.summary: The ocean has absorbed more than 90 percent of the excess heat caused by human-generated climate change since 1971. The world is experiencing the largest national parks of the sea, according to Rita Maria El Zaghloul. The ocean is on the brink of collapse.

articles.title: Rising Orange River Waters Threaten Agriculture, Close Roads in Northern Cape
articles.author: International
articles.summary: Rising water levels in the Orange River have caused significant damage to the agricultural sector in the Lower Orange River region. Authorities have closed several roads and low-lying bridges as the river continues to swell following water releases from the overflowing Vaal and Gariep dams upstream. Farmers report submerged fields, damaged crops and concerns over long-term impacts on food production. The Northern Cape's agricultural sector, heavily reliant on irrigation from the River, is facing major disruptions.

articles.title: Accelerating our efforts to protect Earth's oceans
articles.author: Rita Maria El Zaghloul
articles.summary: Since 1971, the ocean has absorbed more than 90 percent of the excess heat caused by human-generated climate change. The world is experiencing the largest coral-bleaching event on record. Coral reefs provide goods and services worth US$2.7 trillion per year. Only 17.6 percent of land and 8.4 percent of seas are currently protected, with the latter increasing by just 0.5 percent since COP15. The High Ambition Coalition for Nature and People (HAC for N&P) was created to support member countries in their efforts to achieve the 30-by-30 target.

articles.title: The outrageous ignorance of N.J.'s climate-skeptic lawmakers puts us at risk
articles.author: Jennifer M. Coffey
articles.summary: Jennifer M. Coffey is outraged that members of New Jersey's congressional delegation and the state Legislature are promoting an anti-science agenda. The controversy is all over NJPACT REAL — New Jersey Protecting Against Climate Threats, Resilient Environments and Landscapes. The rules are designed to keep people from drowning to death in their homes just as 25 New Jerseyans died in Hurricane Ida.

articles.title: Bolick Farms' Journey: From Hurricane Helene to healing and hope
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated western North Carolina. Bolick Farms, a cattle farm near the New River in Boone, suffered substantial damage. The farm has recovered thanks to resilience, faith and the unwavering support of fellow farmers.    .   and has come out stronger.

articles.title: How Sahara Desert's silent drift is threatening Europe's clean energy ambition
articles.author: Subhadra Srivastava
articles.summary: Saharan dust has far-reaching effects. It can darken snow in the Alps, accelerate melting, and even reach the Arctic. Studies by researchers in the UAE and New York University Abu Dhabi have linked such events to shifts in rainfall and glacial behaviour, with wider implications for climate change.

articles.title: Cost of emissions from five major Australian resource companies more than $900bn, study finds
articles.author: Royce Kurmelovs
articles.summary: A US research team developed a method to link individual companies to specific climate harms and put a dollar figure to the impact. BP, Gazprom, Saudi Aramco, ExxonMobil, Chevron, BP and ExxonMobil were found to be responsible for billions of dollars in damages. The figure runs into the trillions for the world's largest fossil fuel producers. The work provides a foundation for future research to link the activities of specific oil, gas and coal producers to additional climate harms such as drought, flooding and sea level rise.

articles.title: World's biggest iceberg A23a captured from space, twice the size of London, now breaking apart due to...
articles.author: Pravrajya Suruchi
articles.summary: A23a, one of the world's largest icebergs, was photographed by the Ocean and Land Colour Instrument on the European Space Agency's Copernicus Sentinel-3 satellite on April 5, 2025. The iceberg covers an estimated 3,460 square kilometers, which is about twice the size of Greater London. A23a broke off from the Filchner Ice Shelf in Antarctica back in 1986 and has been drifting northwards since late 2023. South Georgia, the iceberg's current neighbor, is a remote and mountainous island, stretching 170 kilometers in length.

articles.title: Heavy rain lashes several parts of Chittoor district
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Heavy rain lashed several parts of Chittoor district on Sunday afternoon. Temperatures soared to 40 degrees Celsius in Nagari and Karveti Nagaram mandals. Punganur and Kuppam mandals received heavy rain in the last 24 hours. Traffic on the Chitoor-Kanipakam road was halted briefly due to snapped powerlines and a couple of partially uprooted poles.

articles.title: Grey County residents can help shape new climate adaptation plan
articles.author: Collingwoodtoday Staff
articles.summary: Grey County is inviting residents to help shape Resilient Grey, the County's new Climate Change Adaptation Plan. The plan aims to increase understanding of how changing weather patterns are affecting our region and how we can build more resilient communities today. Residents are encouraged to go online to the webpage to complete the public survey by May 20, 2025. The final strategy is expected in spring 2026.

articles.title: Fairbanks area prepares for upcoming wildfire season
articles.author: Jack Barnwell
articles.summary: The McDonald Fire was the largest within the Fairbanks North Star Borough since 2004. This year's Alaska wildfires burned less than the recent average, but they still created smoke problems in communities. Jack Barnwell can be contacted at 907-459-7587 or jbarnwell@newsminer.com.

articles.title: Devastating Hailstorm Ravages Shimla's Orchard Belt
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: An intense hailstorm battered Shimla's key agricultural zones on Friday and Saturday. Theog, Kotgarh, and Kumarsain were badly affected. The repercussions for the local farming community have been devastating, reducing fields to wastelands and erasing a year's worth of effort within hours.

articles.title: Another Voice: Sudden changes
articles.author: Crispin B. Hollinshead
articles.summary: The Earth has warmed by less than 3°F in the last 150 years. Sea levels are rising each year. The solution to climate change is complete economic decarbonization and massive carbon sequestration. The current Federal approach focuses on maintaining existing short-term profit structures. Insurance companies can't afford to ignore reality when their losses exceed premium income.

articles.title: Climate change is both sinking and lifting South Africa
articles.author: Muskat Daily
articles.summary: Rising seas threaten South Africa's coastlines, but the ground beneath parts of the country seems to be rising. South Africa hasn't successfully linked climate and ocean discussions, they're often treated as separate issues, according to researchers from Germany. The problem has been that South Africa has not successfully linked the two issues.

articles.title: Europe's firefighters want more funds and staff
articles.author: Beatrice Tridimas
articles.summary: Unions warn Europe's fire services are overstretched as climate change raises the risk of deadly blazes. Firefighters want more funding and better incentives for the millions of volunteers who prop up the system. In Sweden, Romania and Hungary, firefighter numbers shrank two years in a row, declining overall by more than 20%. Germany experienced a year-on-year decline, with numbers dropping 7%. Firefighter numbers in Belgium and Portugal fell 5% and 2%.

articles.title: Former governor of Espaillat urges government to declare entire northern coast in a state of emergency
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Dilloné Ovalles, former governor of Espaillat province, is calling for a state of emergency for the entire northern coast. Heavy rains have devastated the municipality of Gaspar Hernández and the municipal districts of Joba Arriba, Veragua, and Yásica since Tuesday afternoon. The situation is expected to worsen.

articles.title: Killer fungi to spread as climate heats up 随着气候变暖，致命真菌将加速扩散
articles.author: 成为付费会员，阅读FT独家内容
articles.summary: Rising temperatures will drive the global spread of a killer fungus that infects millions of people a year, according to new research on how climate change is stoking severe disease threats. The current global temperature rise is 3.3% and 97% according to the new research.

articles.title: Killer fungi to spread as climate heats up
articles.author: Michael Peel
articles.summary: Rising temperatures will drive the global spread of a killer fungus that infects millions of people a year. The Aspergillus family could expand its reach to more northerly swaths of Europe, Asia and the Americas. Fungi are a particular peril due to their hard-to-detect spores and a shortage of treatments for the diseases they trigger.

articles.title: Scientists raise concerns after observing unexpected shift in bird behavior
articles.author: Patrick Long
articles.summary: Warming temperatures and extreme weather events change the timing of the spring equinox. For migratory birds, the season now begins earlier, as warmer weather comes sooner. Bird migration has a tremendous impact on more than one habitat. Reducing your use of fossil fuels is a good way to help the planet.

articles.title: Extremely rare Eurasian eagle-owl caught flying over Burnley
articles.author: Jack Stott
articles.summary: The Eurasian eagle-owl was captured flying out of a woodland just outside Burnley on Saturday, April 26. It is one of the largest birds of prey in the world, with a wingspan of more than six feet and a total length of 75cm. It can be recognised by its distinctive ear tufts.

articles.title: Earth's warming affecting Americans from coast to coast
articles.author: Casey Ek
articles.summary: According to NASA, 97% of climate scientists agree that humans are causing global warming and climate change. However, only 72% of American adults believe climate change is happening and 59% say it's caused mostly by human activity. According to Yale Climate Opinion Maps, 63% of Americans are somewhat or very worried about global warming.

articles.title: MAY 3, 2025
articles.summary: This week Matter of Fact travels to Oregon where fire officials are preparing residents for wildfire season. There was a 246% increase in the number of structures destroyed by wildfires between 2010 and 2020. The IMMIGRATION CRACKdown has an impact on children.

articles.title: Experts raise red flags as cities expand into high-risk flood zones: 'A complex challenge with no quick fix'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: Cities around the world are expanding into high-risk flood zones. Global warming has been linked to increasing rainfall intensity. People are at risk of drowning, contaminated water, electrocution from downed power lines, and long-term mental health effects from extreme weather events.

articles.title: Several 'overwintering' fires are becoming more active in B.C.'s north
articles.author: Nicholas Johansen
articles.summary: Some of the overwintering fires in Northern B.C. are becoming more active and producing smoke. The fires are not currently threatening highways or infrastructure, but travellers along Highway 77 and the Alaska Highway can expect to see smoke. Other fires in the northern half of the province have recently been sparked.

articles.title: Editorial: Help debunk climate change myths
articles.summary: Donald Trump is a climate change denier. According to a University of Michigan study, 15% of Americans believe that climate change isn't real. The Paris climate agreement to reduce global warming has been ratified by all but four pariah nations: Iran, Libya, Yemen and the United States.

articles.title: Arctic Oscillation Linked to Southern China Winter Wildfires
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Arctic Oscillation (AO) has been linked to the increasing occurrence of winter wildfires in Southern China. AO is a dominant mode of climate variability characterized by shifts in atmospheric pressure patterns over the Arctic and the mid-latitudes. Shifts in the AO alter wind patterns, temperature anomalies, and relative humidity levels, which can influence wildfire ignition and propagation during the winter months.

articles.title: Folk musicians of Rajasthan battle landlessness, rising heat in fight to save ancient art
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The struggle for landlessness and climate change is at the intersection of two pressing issues: landless people and environment change.    .   i.e. the landless and the environment are at the heart of the struggle for the landlessness.

articles.title: Cyprus Warming Nearly Twice as Fast as Global Average, Report Finds
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Cyprus is experiencing climate change at an accelerated rate, with average temperatures rising and severe water shortages projected for future generations, according to an Audit Office report. The island's water supplies are expected to be limited for future.       in the future.

articles.title: Cyprus Warming Nearly Twice as Fast as Global Average, Report Finds
articles.summary: Cyprus is experiencing climate change at an accelerated rate. The average temperature has increased by 1.8°C in Nicosia and 2.9°C  in Limassol over the last century. Annual rainfall has decreased by 87mm (15.6%) over 92 years. 91% of Cyprus is now classified as climatically critical or sensitive.

articles.title: Extreme Compound Events in Equatorial South Atlantic
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: A new study delves into the dynamics of extreme compound events in the equatorial and South Atlantic regions. It highlights the interplay of atmospheric, oceanic, and climatic factors driving these hazardous phenomena. Compound events in this area are becoming more frequent and increasingly synchronized across disparate variables such as sea surface temperature anomalies, storm surges, and precipitation extremes. They pose a threat to ecosystem health, marine biodiversity, and coastal communities.

articles.title: Letters to the Editor — Readers say climate change is real and clean energy is needed
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: It's disheartening to read about the devastating effects of climate change coming to Texas. Ignoring climate change will only increase the suffering of Texas families and strain emergency services, agricultural output and energy grid. The insurance industry knows that climate change is driving up the risks and associated costs. The clean energy tax credits are estimated to provide $144 billion in investments and 190,000 jobs here in Texas.

articles.title: Pakistan records second-hottest April in 65 years
articles.summary: Pakistan experienced its second-hottest April in 65 years, with average temperatures soaring well above historical norms. The hottest day of the month was recorded on April 17 in Shaheed Benazirabad (formerly Nawabshah), where the mercury hit 49°C. There was a 59% reduction in rainfall compared to the national average, intensifying drought conditions in vulnerable areas.

articles.title: An inspiring, productive Climate Action Week in Eagle County
articles.author: Vail Daily
articles.summary: Climate Action Week at Walking Mountains is dedicated to inspiring climate action and fostering collaboration with local climate action partners in Eagle County. From meeting llamas to exploring sustainable snow-melting solutions, the week offers a variety of activities to encourage climate action.

articles.title: SNAP cuts will hurt rural America the most
articles.author: José Andrés
articles.summary: After Hurricane Helene, I helped deliver food and water to western North Carolina, where floods had caused devastating floods. Many of the affected communities are still struggling to recover. I delivered RVs to the area families earlier this month.

articles.title: Empowering Informal Settlements: Community-Led Climate Action for Urban Resilience
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: The World Bank's 2025 report is an analysis of the role grassroots leadership must play in the global climate response. The report highlights successful community-led adaptation projects around the world to illustrate what scalable models can look like. Many donor systems operate under the assumption that community-based organizations cannot manage technical projects.

articles.title: Rising River CO2 Emissions in Northern Permafrost
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: There is evidence of increased riverine carbon dioxide emissions across the vast permafrost regions of the Northern Hemisphere. This discovery highlights a previously underappreciated feedback mechanism that could accelerate climate warming in the coming decades. The study adds a vital piece to the complex puzzle of carbon cycling in cold environments that are warming.

articles.title: People who call Australia home should not reject our values and way of life
articles.author: Chantal Corish
articles.summary: I find it hard to imagine moving permanently to another country. I feel a pang of disbelief when people tell me they are first-generation migrants from somewhere else. That's how I would feel if I ever left beautiful Australia. I would long for it.

articles.title: ⚡Best Quotes, Messages and Greetings To Send on International Firefighters' Day 2025
articles.summary: International Firefighters' Day was established following a tragic wildfire in Australia in 1998 that claimed the lives of five firefighters. Since then, the day has grown into a global movement of respect and gratitude for those in the firefighting profession and for the firefighters' profession.

articles.title: Gardeners issued urgent 'act now' warning for bird feeders and baths
articles.author: Almha Murphy
articles.summary: The UK has just experienced the hottest start to May on record, according to the Met Office. The unusually warm temperatures can pose an issue for many animals, in particular, bird populations. Most UK bird species aren't used to high heat, and an extended hot spell can leave them dangerously dehydrated. Water is one of the best ways to help them cool off.

articles.title: Bracing for climate migration
articles.author: Muhammad Toheed
articles.summary: There are more than 45,000 climate migrants arriving in Karachi every month due to climate change. They are forced to leave their homes and settle in the city's slums. Karachi's urban policies are ill-equipped to handle large-scale displacement. The government needs to create an urgent policy to address the humanitarian crisis.

articles.title: Coalition power plan 'nuked' at poll: climate groups
articles.author: Lloyd Jones
articles.summary: Labor's landslide election victory shows Australians rejected the coalition's nuclear energy plan, according to climate action groups.       .   in the landslide election win shows Australians have overwhelmingly rejected the Coalition's nuke energy plan.  in this case.

articles.title: Coalition power plan 'nuked' at poll: climate groups
articles.author: Lloyd Jones
articles.summary: Labor's landslide election victory shows Australians rejected the coalition's nuclear energy plan, according to climate action groups.       .   in the landslide election win shows Australians have overwhelmingly rejected the Coalition's nuke energy plan.  in this case.

articles.title: Coalition power plan 'nuked' at poll: climate groups
articles.author: Lloyd Jones
articles.summary: Labor's landslide election victory shows Australians rejected the coalition's nuclear energy plan, according to climate action groups.       .   in the landslide election win shows Australians have overwhelmingly rejected the Coalition's nuke energy plan.  in this case.

articles.title: Japan's scorching summers could halt children's outdoor sports by 2060, experts say
articles.author: Julian Ryall
articles.summary: By 2060, summer temperatures in Japan could become so high that outdoor sports for children may need to be suspended during parts of July and August except for the cooler Hokkaido island. Without a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, many areas of the country will become unsuitable for youth sports in the late afternoon.

articles.title: April 4 Letters Part 4: Our Readers' Opinions
articles.summary: The Arctic sea ice extent has decreased in all months and virtually all regions since satellite-based measurements began in the late 1970s. The September 2022 ice extent was 1.88 million square miles, tied with 2010 for 11th lowest in the satellite record. The smallest daily extent of 2022 occurred on Sept. 18, when the total ice extent bottomed out for the summer at 1.8 million sq miles.

articles.title: Rhonda Bannard believes women are the changemakers for climate action and Mother Earth
articles.author: Azcentral
articles.summary: Rhonda Bannard doesn't have a degree in climate or environmental science, but she has a drive to help. President Trump has abandoned efforts to reduce global warming. It could take a generation or more to repair the damage, according to Rhonda.

articles.title: El Paso Is Having Its Dustiest Year Since the Actual Dust Bowl
articles.author: Gizmodo
articles.summary: Drought, wind, and climate change are turning the Borderplex into a morass of airborne grit due to drought, wind or climate change. The Borderplex is covered in a thick layer of grit. The dust is created by the wind and by the drought.

articles.title: Cost of emissions from five major Australian resource companies more than $900bn, study finds
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: US research team developed a method to link individual companies to specific climate harms and put a dollar figure to the impact. Five of Australia's biggest fossil fuel producers could be on the hook for hundreds of billions of dollars in damages. This is the result of a new peer-review study published in the Journal of Climate Research.

articles.title: Europe's firefighters want more funds and staff
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: Europe's fire services are overstretched as climate change raises the risk of deadly blazes, according to firefighter unions in the world's fastest-growing war zone.    .   i   in this regard, they are underinvesting in staff.

articles.title: Absurd (Scary) CO2 Emissions
articles.author: Dissident Voice
articles.summary: Paris '15 climate agreement was supposed to slow down CO2 emissions by 2030. For the first time in modern history, CO2 enters the scientifically established danger zone. In 2016, a worldwide body of climate scientists said that a level of 430 ppm would push the world past its target for avoiding dangerous climate change.

articles.title: Bolick Farms' Journey: From Hurricane Helene to healing and hope
articles.author: Watauga Democrat
articles.summary: In the wake of Hurricane Helene, the landscape of western North Carolina was devastated by the storm's winds and rain.       in the wake   was devastated.  In the aftermath of the storm,  the landscape  was destroyed.

articles.title: 350.org Pacific Reacts To Albanese Win In Australia Federal Elections
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: The result is an indication that Australia isn't falling prey to the divisive politics of the far right, but there is still work to be done. Labour has made climate promises in the past and we intend to hold them accountable to these promises.    .

articles.title: Australia's re-elected government says US-China tussle to be top priority
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: It will focus on global economic uncertainty and what it means for Australia and Australia's place in the world. It will also focus on the economic situation in Australia and the country's position in the global economy. It is expected to focus on Australia's role in it.

articles.title: Volunteers warn more is needed to halt invasive seaweed species
articles.author: RNZ
articles.summary: A hapū tackling the invasive seaweed caulerpa in the Bay of Islands warns it will spread to the rest of the country unless more is invested in stopping it short where it is now. Hundreds of tonnes of it washed ashore after the storms caused by ex-Tropical.

articles.title: Could New Zealand's major cities be at risk of sinking?
articles.author: Newstalk ZB
articles.summary: New Zealand could be at risk of sinking shorelines due to rising sea levels, according to a new study from a group of New Zealand experts. The study was based on a study from the University of Auckland's coastal studies department and was published in the journal "Sustainable Development.

articles.title: Australian election: Voters reject Peter Dutton's vision, giving Labor a remarkable victory and Liberals a ...
articles.author: Jacob Greber
articles.summary: Peter Dutton has been fired from the Liberal Party and its future with him. Anthony Albanese's campaign was as devastating, driven and determined as Dutton's was dreadful. Australians have chosen to face global challenges the Australian way, as Jacob Greber reports.

articles.title: Japan's scorching summers could halt children's outdoor sports by 2060, experts say
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: There have been 100 heat-related child deaths in Japan in the past 20 years. A study warns that youth sports may become unsafe due to heat unless greenhouse gases are reduced in the environment. The study was based on a study by the World Health Organisation.
